title: Neighbors recount vandal spree in Harrisburg
content:
HARRISBURG – Cleanup was underway Sunday after a large group of teenagers coming from the Kipona Festival ransacked a store and smashed up cars in Midtown Saturday night.
The unlikely remains of a crime spree — discarded cheese puffs — littered a 2nd Street sidewalk near Verbeke Street.
“Somebody’s got to do it,” she said after sweeping up the food. “Nobody else is going to come out here and do it.”
The snack bag is from 2nd and Verbeke Mini Market, a convenience store. A clerk there told abc27 a group of teenagers stole and/or destroyed $200-300 in merchandise.
It was part of a vandalism streak: Neighbors and police estimate more than 100 teens mobbed that section of Harrisburg around 10 p.m., after leaving Kipona.
“All hell was breaking loose,” said Betty Krause, a lifelong Midtown resident.
The group smashed up cars parked on the streets, slamming them with trash cans and bikes.
The dangling mirrors that remained on Sunday were mild compared to other reports of broken windshields and caved-in hoods and roofs.
Neighbors say police dusted for fingerprints early Sunday morning; the black marks of the process were still evident on Carter’s gold sedan.
“It’s going to be hard to track those kids down,” Krause said, “because they were from all over.”
A teenager was hit in the leg. Chief Carter said Sunday afternoon it appears the 15-year-old shot himself.
He’ll be okay — the injury was not life-threatening — but police say he’s not cooperating with their investigation.
So far, more than 10 people have filed damage reports with the department, with dozens more cars affected.
But even though police have made no arrests, McAlicher will keep doing what she’s doing.
